questions.text: A healthy 25-year-old software engineer participates in a 10-km charity run. Which of the following muscle does this person use during expiration?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the person has performed a strenuous exercise, so he will be using accessory muscles of respiration along with primary muscle of respiration. Internal intercostals and abdominal recti are the muscles involved.

Muscles involved in Respiration
Primary inspiratory muscles
  • Diaphragm
  • External intercostal muscles
Accessory inspiratory muscles
  • Sternocleidomastoid
  • Scaleni
  • Alae nasi
  • Small muscles of the head & neck
Accessory expiratory muscles
  • Internal intercostal muscles 
  • Rectus Abdominis
  • Internal & external obliques
  • Transversus abdominis

Clinical correlation:

  • The diaphragm is the chief muscle of inspiration.
  • It is supplied by the phrenic nerve ( C3-C5 )
  • Hence transection of the spinal cord above the third cervical segment is fatal without artificial respiration, but transection below the fifth cervical segment is not fatal because, it leaves the phrenic nerves that innervate the diaphragm.

choices.text: Negative at apex but positive at base

questions.solution:
Intrapleural pressure is usually negative. (normally -2.5 mmHg)

During inspiration, it becomes more negative. (-6 mmHg). 

During forced expiration, contraction of the expiratory muscles raises intrapleural pressure to a positive value.

Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the visceral and parietal pleura.

questions.text: The intrapleural pressure is negative both during inspiration and expiration because______

choices.text: Thoracic cage and lung recoil in opposite direction

questions.solution:
The intrapleural pressure is negative both during inspiration and expiration because the thoracic cage and lung recoil in opposite direction.

The 2 factors that lead to a negative or subatmospheric intrapleural pressure are:

  • The lungs, with their elastic properties, tend to collapse, and the chest wall, with its elastic properties, tends to spring out. When these two opposing forces pull on the intrapleural space, a negative pressure, or vacuum, is created.
  • The continuous suction of excess fluid into the lymphatic channels.

Applied aspect:

In cases of pneumothorax, intrapleural pressure suddenly becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. Thus instead of its normal negative value, intrapleural pressure becomes zero. Hence lungs collapse and the chest wall spring out.

questions.text: The intrapleural pressure (cm of H2O)  at the beginning of inspiration is around
questions.solution:
The normal intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration is about -3.4 cm H2O (-2.5 mmHg).

Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the lung pleura and the chest wall pleura. During normal inspiration, expansion of the chest cage pulls outward on the lungs with greater force and creates more negative pressure.

At the peak of normal inspiration, it is about -8.15 cm H2O (-5.4 mm Hg).

Note: 1mm Hg = 1.36 cm H2O

questions.text: With reference to atmospheric pressure, what is the alveolar pressure at the end of normal inspiration (in cms of H2O)?
questions.solution:
At the end of inspiration, the alveolar pressure is zero with reference to the atmospheric pressure.

Whenever alveolar pressure equals atmospheric pressure, alveolar pressure is said to be zero. This happens when no air is moving in or out of the lungs.

During inspiration, the diaphragm contracts, causing the volume of the thorax to increase. As lung volume increases, the pressure in the lungs must decrease. (Boyle’s law states that P × V is constant at a given temperature.) Halfway through inspiration, the alveolar pressure falls below atmospheric pressure (−1 cm H2O). The pressure gradient between the atmosphere and the alveoli drives airflow into the lung. Air flows into the lungs until, at the end of inspiration, alveolar pressure is once again equal to the atmospheric pressure; the pressure gradient between the atmosphere and the alveoli has dissipated, and airflow into the lungs ceases.

During expiration, alveolar pressure rises to about +1 cm of H2O.

questions.text: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between _______
questions.solution:
Transpulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure. (Mnemonic TAP: Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Pleural pressure)

It is the pressure difference between that in the alveoli and that on the outer surfaces of the lungs, and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instant of respiration, called the recoil pressure.

questions.text: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm H20)?
questions.solution:
Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure.

  • C= ΔV/ΔP

In this case,

ΔV= 1000 mL

ΔP= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O

The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration

Therefore the compliance is,

C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman has pulmonary compliance of 0.2 L/cm H2O and an alveolar pressure of 4 cmH2O and an intrapleural pressure of -5 cmH2O at the beginning of inspiration. What is the transpulmonary pressure (in cmH2O) when this woman inhales 600mL of air ?
questions.solution:
The transpulmonary pressure would be 12 cmH2O when she inhales 600mL of air.

Transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) is the difference between alveolar pressure (Palv) and intrapleural pressure (Pip). It is given by the formula: Ptp = Palv-Pip. Inspiration causes a negative change in both the Palv and Pip. Lung compliance is the extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure.

In a normal adult, the pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O of both lungs together. Hence, expanding the lungs by 200 mL of inspired air will require an increase in Ptp by 1 cm H2O.

Given:
Pulmonary compliance = 0.2 L/cm H2O = 200 ml/cm H20
Alveolar pressure at the beginning of inspiration = 4 cmH2O
Intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration = -5 cmH2O
Volume of air inhaled = 600mL (0.6L)

Step 1: Calculate the initial transpulmonary pressure (Ptp).

Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Intrapleural pressure; Initial transpulmonary pressure = 4 cmH2O - (-5 cmH2O) = 9 cmH2O

Step 2: Use the lung compliance formula to find the change in transpulmonary pressure.

Lung compliance = Change in volume / Change in transpulmonary pressure.

Pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O. Hence, to expand the lungs by 200 mL of inspired air, it will require an increase in Ptp by 1 cm H2O. So, for 600 ml inspired air, the compliance is = 600 mL / 200 mL/cm H2O = 3 cmH2O

Step 3: Calculate the transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) after inhaling 600mL of air.

During inspiration, the alveolar pressure (Palv) decreases, and the intrapleural pressure (Pip) becomes more negative.

Final transpulmonary pressure = Initial transpulmonary pressure + change in transpulmonary pressure; Final transpulmonary pressure = 9 cmH2O + 3 cmH2O = 12 cmH2O.

questions.text: Compared to a gas-ventilated lung,  a liquid-ventilated lung _____
questions.solution:
A liquid-ventilated lung is more compliant compared to a gas-ventilated lung.

Compliance is a measure of distensibility. In a gas-filled lung, surface tension and elastic recoil forces act to collapse the lung and thus reduce compliance.

  • When the lungs are filled with air, there is an interface between the alveolar fluid and the air in the alveoli; so, there is surface tension.
  • But, in the case of the saline solution-filled lungs, there is no air–fluid interface and there is no surface tension, making it more compliant.
  • Hence, the pressure–volume curve obtained with saline measures only the tissue elasticity.
  • The difference in the curves generated during inflation and deflation, termed hysteresis, is not present in the saline-generated curves.

questions.text: The factor responsible for hysteresis is _______
questions.solution:
Surfactant is the factor responsible for hysteresis.

Difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed as hysteresis.  

The alveolar environment and, specifically, the secreted factors that help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contribute to hysteresis.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
• The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with respect to the change in intrapleural pressure, which is compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Applied aspect:

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: In the pressure–volume graph shown below, compliance of lung is represented by _________.
questions.solution:
In the given pressure–volume graph:

  • A – Compliance of chest
  • B – Compliance of lung
  • C – Compliance of lung and chest wall 

The equilibrium position is at functional residual capacity (FRC), where the expanding force on the chest wall is exactly equal to the collapsing force on the lungs. FRC is also known as relaxation volume and represents the amount of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

At the point where volume= FRC,

  • Intraalveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure and considered as zero.
  • Intrapleural pressure is negative (-2.5 mmHg)
  • Transpulmonary pressure = Intraalveolar pressure – intrapleural pressure = 0 – (-2.5 mmHg) = +2.5 mmHg.  

For compliance of lung – Pressure considered is Transpulmonary pressure. So at FRC, Transpulmonary pressure is positive (+2.5 mmHg). Hence, B indicates compliance of lung.  

For compliance of chest wall – Pressure considered is intrapleural – atmospheric pressure. At FRC, this value is -2.5 mmHg. Hence, A represents compliance of the chest wall.  

When the volume is FRC, the combined lung and chest-wall curve intersects the X-axis at an airway pressure of zero. Hence, C represents the combined chest wall and lung compliance.

questions.text: What is specific compliance of lung?
questions.solution:
Specific compliance is obtained by dividing compliance by functional residual capacity.

Types of compliance:

  • Static compliance: It is measured at rest.
  • Dynamic compliance: It is measured during breathing. It considers airflow resistance or impedance into account. It is maximum in medium-sized bronchi.
  • Specific compliance: 
    • Lung compliance is volume-dependent. 
    • It is greater at low lung volumes than at high lung volumes. For this reason, the term specific compliance is often used to denote compliance with reference to the original lung volume.
  • The total compliance of a normal person near the normal end-expiratory lung volume (functional residual capacity [FRC]) is about 0.1 L/cm H2O.
  • The compliance of the lungs is about 0.2 L/cm H2O.

Applied aspect:

In case of emphysema, compliance is increased but specific compliance decreases (because FRC is severely elevated).

questions.text: Work done in quiet breathing is (kg-m/min)______
questions.solution:
Work done in quiet breathing is 0.5 kg-m/min.

Estimates of the total work of quiet breathing range from 0.3 up to 0.8 kg-m/min.

The work of breathing can be calculated from the pressure-volume curve.

The value rises markedly during exercise, but the energy cost of breathing in normal individuals represents less than 3% of the total energy expenditure during exercise.

Applied aspect:

In the case of COPD, airway resistance increases (obstruction to outflow). Hence, the patient should take slow, deep breathing.

In the case of restrictive lung disease, viscous resistance increases. Hence, the patient is advised rapid, shallow breathing.

questions.text: Work of breathing is mostly due to____
questions.solution:
Most of the work of breathing is due to surface tension elasticity.

Work of Breathing:

  • Elastic/Compliance work (65%): Surface tension (2/3rd) + Tissue elasticity (1/3rd)
  • Non elastic work (35%): Tissue/Viscus resistance (7%) + Airway resistance (28%)

Work of quiet breathing = 0.3 - 0.8 kg-m/min

Maximum work of breathing = 10kg-m/min

questions.text: If the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be?
questions.solution:
If lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be minimum volume as the opposing force by the chest wall would be non existant. 

The yellow line in the above graph denotes the compliance of lungs alone. According to the graph, when the pressure (x axis)  inside the lung is zero, there is some volume of air lesser than FRC still present (y axis) inside the lungs which is less than the functional residual capacity and residual volume which can be called as minimum volume.

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to:

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in conc. of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.solution:
The difference between the inflation and the deflation paths is called hysteresis.

It exists because a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway, due to a deficit of surfactant at the air-water interface, than to keep an open airway from closing, as then it has abundant surfactant.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year old man who suffered a head injury in an automobile accident. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne–Stokes breathing. In this case, the person breathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not for an additional interval. This pattern repeats itself about every minute.

It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heart failure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normal individuals.

This increased response occurs apparently due to the disruption of neural pathways that normally inhibit respiration. In such an individual, increased sensitivity to CO2 causes relative hyperventilation, lowering the arterial Pco2. During the resultant apnoea, the arterial Pco2 rises again to normal, but the respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2. Breathing ceases, and the cycle repeats.
